Friction_Taxonomy.logical_dna_rule: The process is historically slow because the caseworker is required to obtain three separate contractor estimates to determine the company for installation (e.g., wheelchair ramps).
Requires detailed 'face-to-face' documentation that straight Medicare does not mandate; successful appeals typically add a fixed 3-day processing window.
In regions with only one specialist, illness triggers a care gap; the PN must coordinate with HHA generalist nurses to bridge dressing changes until a specialist is available.
To qualify for specialized home wound care, the patient must require at least one other skilled service (RN or PT); losing these services renders them ineligible even if the wound is open.
Most HHAs only process new admissions Monday–Friday; a Friday discharge means the patient sits without home services until Monday unless the PN secures a weekend exception.
Durable Medical Equipment (hospital bed, O2 concentrator, wound vac) must be at the home before discharge; vendor backlog or insurance pre-auth for DME delays the safe transition date.
The single HHA intake coordinator is out sick, on PTO, or overwhelmed with referrals; the PN cannot confirm the admission slot or start-of-care date until intake processes the referral.
The primary caregiver has not been trained on wound care, catheter maintenance, or medication administration; discharge cannot proceed safely until the family demonstrates competency.
The medication list from the discharging facility does not match what the HHA received; the PN must reconcile discrepancies before the first home visit to avoid adverse drug events.
The HHA requires a home safety evaluation (grab bars, ramp, clear pathways) before start-of-care; if the home fails inspection, modifications must be arranged before the patient can return.
The HHA does not have a nurse or aide available in the patient's zip code; the PN must find an alternative agency or negotiate coverage with a more distant branch.
The patient's preferred or nearest HHA is out-of-network for their insurance plan; the PN must identify an in-network agency willing to take the referral or initiate a single-case agreement.

Family members disagree about whether the patient should go home vs. a facility; the PN must facilitate alignment on the home health plan while staying within scope (not making clinical recommendations).

Medical transport (wheelchair van, stretcher transport) is unavailable or unscheduled for the discharge date; the PN must coordinate with transport vendors and confirm timing with the HHA's first-visit schedule.
The physician's home health orders were not faxed, were incomplete, or were sent to the wrong HHA; the PN must track down the orders and confirm receipt before start-of-care can be scheduled.
HHA operates on reduced holiday staffing; admissions and first visits are suspended over holiday weekends, pushing the start-of-care date out regardless of patient readiness.
